title: Archaeologists in Croatia use dogs to sniff out 3,000-year-old Iron Age human remains
text:
Dogs' naturally powerful sense of smell has been put to use by Croatian scientists to uncover human remains dating back to the Iron Age - nearly 3,000 years ago.

The new canine technique has uncovered six new burial chests containing human bones and artefacts along the Velebity mountains in Croatia.

Experts said the dogs can smell even ancient human remains, and noticed they could locate excavated graves even after all traces of people were removed.

Sniffer dogs could be better for archaeological excavations than even sophisticated radar techniques, due to their naturally accurate sniffing ability.

The ancient hilltop fort of Drvišica along Croatia's Velebity mountains dates back to the 8th century BC

'Dogs' noses obviously don't make mistakes,' says Professor Vedrana Glavaš at the University of Zadar in Croatia.

'Many archaeologists are looking for burial sites of settlements,' she said. 'I think dogs can solve their problems.'

After previously discovering tombs in an ancient cemetery in the Drvišica hillfort, Professor Glavaš contacted dog trainer Andrea Pintar, with the hope of being able to find out more, according to the Guardian.

Good girl! While sniffer dogs are well-known for their use in criminal investigations, experts say they are currently under-utilised in archaeology

Professor Vedrana Glavaš holds bronze buttons discovered during an excavation.

Mr Pintar brought three Belgian Malinois and one German Shepherd to the site – the dogs had previously been working to sniff out graves for criminal investigations.

All the canines were able to discover the location of all three graves that had already been located by a human team, even though the graves had been removed of human remains and artefacts.

Bodies laid to rest around 3,000 years ago lie in the ancient cemetery of the Drvišica hillfort, in the Velebit mountains along the Adriatic coast, Croatia

Professor Glavaš said the dogs were likely to have detected the aroma of decomposed bodies, which had likely been absorbed by the porous rock around the excavated soil.

Even more impressively, the dogs accurately identified six new tombs that Professor Glavaš was then able to excavate.

The newly discovered tombs consist of small stone burial chests, each containing small bones from human fingers and feet, as well as artefacts such as buckles.

The ancient inhabitants of the hilltop fort of Drvišica most likely died impoverished, due to the windy conditions and the difficulty of growing crops.

While dogs are frequently used to detect human remains in criminal investigations, their potential as four-legged archaeologists is yet to be fully explored.

Dogs also provide a cheaper and less destructive method of uncovering fragile burial sites than high-tech methods such as ground-penetrating radar (GPR), electrical resistivity, and remote sensing.

The study was published in the Journal of Archaeological Method and Theory.
description: Croatian scientists have been using sniffer dogs to uncover ancient tombs dating back nearly 3,000 years, after realising the animals were able to detect ancient human remains.
